title: ANZ slashes price of wealth unit for IOOF
text:
ANZ says the deal – which remains subject to APRA approval following July changes to the SIS Act - is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2020 and will add around 20 basis points to its common equity tier one (CET1).

IOOF CEO Renato Mota said he was pleased to get the deal over the line and create certainty for shareholders and employees of the pensions and investments business.

IOOF CEO Renato Mota "The transaction remains compelling". Eamon Gallagher

"The strategic rationale for the transaction remains compelling and we continue to be confident in the significant benefits it will deliver," Mr Mota said.

"The transaction will meaningfully increase the scale and footprint of our core business."

Mr Mota said the $125 million in savings from the original $975 million purchase price would be used to reduce debt.

“We were relying on borrowing to finance the original price, so the most immediate impact of the new terms is to borrow less which also provides us with some strategic options going forward,” Mr Mota said.

IOOF shares soared following the announcement, trading 9 per cent higher in early trade while ANZ shares edged up 0.4 per cent.

Advertisement

The prospect of a discount to the billion dollar price tag agreed to more than a year ago has been floated by a number of analysts after a series of firesales in the wealth management sector.

The 12.8 per cent reduction in the headline price sees the multiple paid by IOOF for the business fall to 13.5 times from 15.5 times.

Under the new terms the reduced price contributes to a lower warranty cap which allows IOOF to revert back to ANZ if any issues are discovered following the integration of the business.

A clause that would see ANZ and IOOF commit to a minimum 20 year period of working together has also been removed however Mr Mota stressed this did not preclude the two parties from collaborating but merely provided flexibility.

The transaction was placed in limbo after the prudential regulator attempted to have five IOOF directors and executives including then chairman George Vernados and former CEO Chris Kelaher banned from the superannuation industry.

The regualtor lost the case after Justice Jayne Jagot dismissed the claims as "unpersuasive" adding to a series of high profile court defeats suffered by the regulators in the aftermath of the Hayne royal commission.
description: Bank sells wealth arm after cutting the multiple to 13.5 times from 15.5 times and gaining approval from the trustee.
